Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Profile dug on a NW aspect just below/at a crack likely from 2/13 that ran the width of the entire slope across several micro ridges. Test results seem skewed from the previous release of tension on the slope. On the uptrack on a West aspect three large whumphs from 3rd or 4th skier. No signs of instability on the surface before or after. Additional whumph on the second lap in the same area at about 9000ft. Collapse suspect in facets at Jan 19 interface. Facets were moist on West aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: Poor pit location;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Started at Aspen Grove and went to take a safe look at UFO Bowls. There were some point releases from storm snow but nothing that propagated across the bowls. Snowpack is still very shallow for time of year up there. Hopefully the snow piles up with storms this week. This snow profile proved that I will stay away from the steeper high elevation runs in the area. The bottom 35cm (NSF) is still absolutely rotten. No signs of healing. Best low angle riding of the year in these zones. Only getting better this week!

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The weakest interface is >1m deep in the snowpack, but several weak interfaces persist in the upper snowpack as well. A slide triggered in the upper layers would likely step down to the deepest weak layer, resulting in a very large and dangerous avalanche.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug in upper Fruit Bowl on the NW side of the far East ridge (below the common boot pack). Was hoping to find a spot lee to both SE and NE winds. This spot is definitely lee to SE winds, maybe more cross-loaded, if anything, to NE winds. No major windslab present. A widespread 5mm crust capped 25-30cms of new snow. When I pried off my ECT block, it sheared fairly easily on a layer between two MFCRs around 205cm. I had chosen not to call these crusts two separate layers, but this laminated layer between seems to be weak and faceted.
